segments.text: Yeah, ours, except the summer, we had jobs in the summertime.
Ours was classroom instruction.
And we were involved, of course, with leadership, everything about leadership.
And how many courses did you teach a semester?
How'd they work?
Did you teach one in psychology and one in leadership?
What was your teaching load like?
It was a progressive psychology with a plea for the first year, basic psychology.
And then it progressed on leadership to finally the first class, when Pat went to Massachusetts, preparing them for those situations.
Role players, role players.
Situations that they could be in the front.
And it worked, too, because I told you about the cadets not going to a basic course after graduation and got into Korea.
And I talked to them while I was there.
I went over with General Taylor, Maxwell Taylor.
Now, there's an outstanding, there's an intellectual for you.
Tell me about him.
Oh, he's a...
He's one, too, he's got just as near to all the qualities that I think that a rounded leader would possess as Marshall.
You know, he's in that pattern.
Except he's got one advantage over Marshall.
He's a real handsome guy.
He's a, even at old age now, he's up in his seventies, he's still a, he still is a Hollywood looking, because he has nice hair features, and he's done everything.
He's an airborne commander.
He's written books.
He's an intellectual, can sit down with any Ph.D. and any inspector he wants to.
He's not an expert on everything, but he's sure got a speaking knowledge of practically anything you want to discuss.
Because he's a scholar.
He's still studying right now.
And just such an impressive individual.
And all of his time is organized.
And so I learned a lot by associating him with West Point, in particular going on this trip.
Now, he'll go to the barbershop to get a haircut.
Most people go and pick up the paper or magazine.
Not him.
He's always working on something.
Reading it won't be fiction.
It may be some very scholarly work that he wanted to be sure of.
His time is all organized.
And he plays tennis.
Obviously, he plays tennis.
He's an expert.
He's really a top-notch senior type of citizen.
Of course, I'm not sure he plays anymore because he's so old.
But he won't play with anybody that's not better than he is.
Of course, that's one of the big problems right there, because he wants to challenge.
He wants to be pushed or stretched, you know.
So I say he was a very...

For West Point, he's the one who introduced this military sidecar and leadership back, just like General MacArthur did, although it was a little different than what MacArthur did, because he felt as superintendent, these are the things he needed.
But on this trip, he was going, and General MacArthur had just been relieved.
And so he was going to represent the chief of staff, really the president, I guess, but the chief of staff of the Army and the chairman of the Joint Chiefs,
for instructions to General Ridgway.
You remember, he took MacArthur's place.
So he invited a member of the MP&L to go with him because he knew that the recent graduates had very high casualties.
And you had comparison.
The class of 49 attended the basic course, and they were .
The class of 50 didn't, and they were sent there.
And so we wanted to learn as much as we could.
about preparation for the class that was just graduating, and also was there a dramatic difference between the two as far as cadets are concerned.
And so he invited me.
I was the one who was named to go, which I was just delighted because being there at West Point and not in the Corral, I figured that sitting out the Korean War, I'd never get promoted
even the colonels, because after all, we got people fighting now, and I knew I didn't deserve it.
So you were eager to get in that war?
Well, no, no, that's currently a little too far.
Oh, okay.
Then let me ask you this, what were your feelings about that war?
I mean, would you have rather stayed at West Point, or did you want to go back to combat?
Well, see, I was, my conscience bothered me, see, because
Here I am, see?
And I was ambitious, because I wanted to progress.
And I knew that I was sidetracking myself.
Now, that was wonderful living there at West Point, working those cadets with an inspiration.
Because they are really funny.
I was also in charge of the yearbook.
And the cadets do all the work.
And I've told you, they have a curfew.
They have to go to bed.
And they have to go out and get advertised.
and do all their schoolwork.
And to plan that book means that many of them are working up there on the book at night instead of studying.
Of course, they have to be pretty smart kids to do this, because that's pretty tough, West Point in particular, since you can't crack the books like you do elsewhere.
So here I am with a beautiful set of quarters.
My wife's happy.
She's got a music class.
Everything's going along fine.
I love football.
So this was an opportunity to go.
And I had an opportunity, the reason I say that, to stay there.
Because they said, oh, great.
Well, we need battalion commanders.
See, I was lieutenant colonel at the time.
And I probably could have pulled it to where I stayed there.
But I'm not going to exaggerate and say that I was just so eager.
And they said, oh, no, because it wasn't that way.
I went there, and they gave me an opportunity to see firsthand what was going on and interview all of these cadets.
With Maxwell Taylor.
With him, too.
Now, he wasn't superintendent any longer.
He was the Pentagon after he was gone.
I think he was chief of operations.
So we left, and all this time aboard that plane, we were on a constellation.
You know, the old full-motor propeller jobs.
We had to land.
I guess we landed in.
Tacoma, and then in Aleutians for refueling, and then to Japan.
And like some of those around in sleep, not him, he would be busy.
One, he speaks several languages.
So while he's there, he's reviewing his Chinese and Korean.
He's got a card file.
I don't know what his system is, but he's studying all that stuff.
Finally, he looks at his watch, and he says, well, it's cocktail time.
So he goes, gets up into his kind of compartment.
This was a VIP configured place.
And he puts on a sports jacket.
And he says, ready for the drink.
He'll take one cocktail, wave it around, you know.
Now he's ready to talk, visit with people.
So he'd come and sit down by me, and if somebody else said anything, he'd say, excuse me, I'd like to talk to Andrew.
So he'd ask me all about MPML, you know, how has it been receiving cadets, do you have any problems, anything I can do.
Pretty soon he's got a good readout of everything we do and what the situation is.
Then there are other people that they always do go out on these tours that represent everyone, a supply guy.
You know, the word goes out, we have room for 10 people, whatever it is.
Who do you want to go to?
The war emperor.
And he goes and talks to them.
Then he looked at his watch and says, all right, it's time to eat.
So we eat the meal.
And visiting time's over, then he's back working.
And we finally doze off in our seats while he's still doing something.
Now we land.
Each time we land, both being the first one to be Tacoma,
He gets out and exercises.
Back and forth he walks, back and forth, back and forth.
We land in Aleutians.
He says, all right, let's walk from the plane where we were up to the hangar.
He said, the time we get up there at a certain point and back, it'll be refueled and be ready to go.
So we did that.
Then when we got to Japan, and I was very fortunate,
Because he said, now, you stay with me, and you receive all these briefings, too, because I think this will be of interest to you, and you might learn something that would be helpful.
So I was able to sit with him in Tokyo for the briefings there about the war and everything about the situation.
Now, this is interesting because they're leaders.
MacArthur had already been relieved and gone, but MacArthur's staff,
is the one who's briefing us on the entire situation, including his G2, his old friend, you know, that's been with him all these years.
I can't call his name.
Then we went to Korea, to General Ridgway's headquarters.
And, you know, MacArthur had a peculiar setup.
Of course, he wore both hats, both in Japan, and also he wore his Korean hat, the Spartan's hat.
Plus, he had a split command.
The Corps under Allman, yeah, it was Allman, reported directly back to him with his hat in Tokyo and not to the hat of the overall command in Korea.
So he had a split command there.
And very few people ever understood it or why he had it.
So of course, the first thing Ridgway did was he consolidated where that corps reports to him the same as the other corps.
But MacArthur, for some reason, wanted that direct link to that.
Because he had his previous chief of staff, so he'd seen him done.
And he felt that he would have control of that.
And I say that's bothered military people ever since then, why you never want to split command.
You can have nothing but trouble.
And they were even competing for support.
So I went there, and General Ridgway's new headquarters, or his headquarters appeared, since he was moving back to take over MacArthur.
And Van Fleet, I think it was, took over the command, or Ridgway's command.
So of course, the first thing Ridgway was, he said, the Corps reports to you, like it did to me.
I had a briefing, and then I stayed with him to the corps.
What did they tell you at the briefing?
The situation?
Yeah, just the situation.
They didn't get it about who got relieved or anything like that.
In fact, everybody stayed completely awake.
Sometimes they'd refer to a gentleman who said this, but it has to do with the background of what they were doing.
Went to the corps, got the briefing, both corps, and to some of the divisions with him.
And then he went to go back to Tokyo, but he had told
the headquarters there in Seoul that he wanted the headquarters in Seoul as far as the south.
The front line was in Seoul, right north of Seoul.
He told me what my mission was and told them.
He wanted me provided with transportation and anything I needed.
Oh, they said, sure.
As long as I briefed them on the way back what I saw and what I intended to take back.
So I had free reign to contact every single cadet.
And some of them were up under fire.
Some of them were artillery units.
One was down in the engineer.
He had a diving suit on.
He was down in the bottom of the Han River with a torch cutting some of the wreckage of the bridge down there.
Of course, I didn't go down there to talk to him.
That's where he came up from.
What they had done, because of that yo-yo back and forth in Seoul, the engineers had equipment to rebuild the bridge.
And they were in the way.
Then the Chinese came in.
And the Chinese and the Koreans attacked.
And they got all the way to Seoul.
So the engineers, rather than haul that out, just dug with a bulldozer and buried all of that equipment.
That is the bridging, railing, and all that steel down in the Kwan River.
And what did these cadets say?
Well, they were just like they're trained.
They said, oh, they'd have been helpful, but we've gotten along all right.
And the comparison between the ones who had the basic school, and that wasn't a great deal of difference.
Of course, the class of 49 said, yes, it was helpful.
But the 50, they really didn't know.
They said, I think this is just a small-arm war.
You just get killed because you're up there.
You have close-in combat.
And of course, they all agree, as anybody, that of course it would be helpful to have more, particularly that engineer.
See, he's not an engineer because he graduated from West Point.
He had to go to engineering school to learn how to be a second lieutenant engineer.
So the consensus was that they needed more schooling.
Yeah.
They would agree that it would have been very helpful.
But you could come to one conclusion that when the chips are down, they'll produce what the military education they have at West Point.
Mainly because to graduate from West Point, you have to be a pretty damn good...
young man.
Is that what you told Maxwell Taylor when you went back?
Yeah, of course.
My purpose, and I got complimented on it by the superintendent and the commandant, mainly the commandant because he's really the one that runs the Corps of Cadets.
I told the cadets that
You know, the word came back, and they do that in every war.
We've been trained in problems.
Korea is not like any other war we've ever had.
So even if you've been to school, we've wasted all this time because, look, here we've got to do it this way.
But the truth of the matter is, many of them were relearning exactly what's in the manuals to begin with.
You get the time to stop at 425.
Oh, we'll stop as soon as the end of this duty.
We'll stop whenever you want.
And the manuals of sound.
Everybody keep relearning.
What if they go into that?
They wouldn't have to relearn it.
The same thing about fire and movement, plan, preparation.
Doing it like it's supposed to be rather than improvising.
Of course, you can be creative in certain things.
But to fight as a unit, you've got to go about the basics of what you've been taught.
If not, you've just got a mob going out.
But the cadets, the class of 51, they went to basic school.
And of course, the war was kind of shut down about the next year, 52, I guess it was.
And we were doing better then because we got sort of boxed in on that Korean War.
Yeah, right.
Now, of course, the Korean War had a couple of very interesting affairs.
One was MacArthur's firing.
What was your opinion of that?
Well, I think you really had no other choice.
Either that or Truman would have to resign because you can't.
See, MacArthur, in all his brilliance,
He was a very arrogant individual.
He didn't have much respect for Truman.
Well, not many people did.
I recall an election, everybody just laughed.
You couldn't find anybody who was for Truman.
And that's the reason the guy with the mustache in New York, he had a shoe in, you know.
This little comical guy.
Before the election, you couldn't find anybody for Truman.
Dale went out and voted for him, see.
Because he wasn't a comical little guy.
He had that squeaky voice and certainly a terrible speech maker.
But he, like we were talking about others, he had standards.
And even though he was involved with our politics in Kansas, nobody ever could find anything that tarnished his reputation, even though he worked for the Pendergast machine.
Kansas City, yeah.
Yeah.
And so he was a little guy that had standards and a strong feeling and probably will go down in history as one of our great presidents because of accomplishments.
Of course, he had a lot of help with Marshall, for example, a lot of good people.
But he made the decision.
And so he should be given credit.
So MacArthur placed him in an untenable position.
See, he was going along with him until he just flat-wrote members of Congress
contradicting what the president said and disagreeing with the policy.
And in essence says, I'm going ahead and do it like it should be done, see, in the way he thought it should be done.
Now, he probably was correct on his strategy.
But we don't have an anarchy in this country if we ever get in a position where the military can just disregard what you're saying.
Two, that he had no
He had everything against him.
See, the Joint Chiefs of Staff, all younger than him, much younger, you know.
He hardly even knew them.
They were all, he looked at them as plebs at the military academy, which is, while he was superintendent, they were even plebs.
So he just ignored them, see.
And he didn't figure the president, that's all.
He just thought he could do that.
Of course, I can't read his mind what he thought, but his action indicated.
Now, we had a little situation at West Point that turned out all right.
Because I have great respect and admire MacArthur.
I think he's one of our great leaders, but not perfect by a long shot.
In our yearbook, I said I was the awesome charge of the yearbook.
I have all four of our yearbooks over there.
We wanted to dedicate this during the Korean War.
dedicate the yearbook to General MacArthur.
So it had all gone to press.
It was dedicated to him.
And we had his picture in it.
And here comes the president, and he relieved General MacArthur.
So the cadets came to me and said, what are we going to do?
So I said, General MacArthur has been relieved of our yearbook.
I said, you want it to continue to be?
Oh, yes, sir.
But we have the same fee.
I said, well, let's plan on doing it, but I'll have to go clear with the commandant, who's Paul D. Harkins, who's up in Dallas now.
He's still alive and living in Dallas.
So I went to Paul D. He was a colonel at that time.
He retired as a lieutenant general.
He was one of the first commanders in Vietnam.
And he said, well, what do the cadets say?
I said, they want to leave that yearbook just like it is.
Plus, it cost us a heck of a lot of money to redo that and take all that.
Anyway, General MacArthur knows we've dedicated this book to him.
And this would really be a slapping insult to somebody who thinks that, see, once again, we've entered into politics, which is not.
He said, well, I certainly agree with you.
He said, I know the superintendent will agree.
So he just called him on the telephone.
And he didn't ask him.
He said, this is what we're going to do.
And the superintendent said, oh, yes.
He had a different suit than Michael Taylor's long gone.
So we had the book out and we made the presentation, which they always do.
The cadets go up to the White House and make a presentation of their book.
Naval Academy does the same thing to the president.
And the president, he didn't have anything to say about that card.
He also, deep down in his heart, he respected him.
But he said, I just can't accept that.
And, uh,
There was another affair, of course, that was going on in Washington at this time and sweeping across the country.
And that was this McCarthyism and the intense anti-communism.
And even by 1953, when you were in Iran, of course, with the attacks that Senator McCarthy leveled against the army.
And I was wondering what your opinion of McCarthyism was.
Well, it's very difficult to express that in words.
I don't think the man was normal.
Of course, we know now he was an alcoholic.
He was like a mad dog.
Yeah, he got the general of the army.
also the Secretary of the Army, but the Secretary of the Army kind of stood up to him.
But that general, he just, boy, he just, the general was right.
See, that's the hell about him.
No question about it.
And I think MacArthur knew that.
I mean, MacArthur, because he played for the media.
Oh, that's a dark page in our history, wasn't it?
Well, did that have any impact at the officers up at West Point?
Did they ever discuss this man?
Well, I really not in that context.
I don't remember anybody being not as much as critical of the unjust treatment of him.
But they still browbeat.

members of congress get a great kick out of when they get witnesses just here recently you know on the tank the m1 tank they were getting a general who's a project manager and he had the other people in he kind of talked back to this guy which that's not good technique he's going to point they're the last control thing but he was telling about the gao
And their findings of how inefficient, expensive, and really stupid the M1 tank project is because you wouldn't order all these things before you had the deficiencies fixed, you know.
And this general, I forget who his name, all the generals now knew they'd been on aid and most of my contemporaries were all gone.
And this general explained what the situation was.
He said, are you saying that the GA report is a lie?
He said, no, I'm not saying that.
I'm telling you what the situation is.
He said, but the GAO, if you say it's not a lie, not going to lie.
They say it's different than you.
So this general finally said, well, do you believe me?
Am I lying?
Well, he
kind of backed off and said, well, no, this seems to be a different.
He said, yes.
I think we're expert.
Nobody in GAO is the expert in this field, and they're not.
I don't care if they're retired and then go to work for the GAO.
They're still not up to date.
The only one who's up to date is the project manager and those that are actually tested and working on it.
I don't know of any time that we've ever had people that go up on the hill
to purposely mislead anybody.
They'd be foolish if they did, because, gosh, the truth.
You can't hide these things.
And I've heard them go up and be perfectly frank about mistakes that we made.
Yes, we should have done it.
But McCarthy sees it that way, and I'm playing for the media, particularly.
But just think of the really good people who he ruined their lives.
by guilt, by association.
No, I have to say that's a dark day in history.
There were some who were communists, or at least leaned towards communism, but not the large number that, especially out in Hollywood, it couldn't write.
no livelihood.
So what they had to do, they wrote under pen names.
They still did the same thing, but didn't get near as much money because they couldn't demand money.
It's almost a handout.
They'd write a screenplay or that and peddle it.
And they'd say, well, you know, we can't use any of your material because you've been blackballed.
Well, we've been in trouble.
So they changed their name.
Or let somebody else's name be put on.
And years later, some of those people are exonerated.
You can't just like sending somebody to jail for 20 years and find out they're innocent like he said all the time.
How do you ever compensate for that?
Impossible.
Well, would you like to say anything else about West Point before we move on to Iran?
No, I can't think of anything.
Well, let's go to Iran, but let's wait until tomorrow.
Okay.
And then we'll start with the really fascinating period in Iran.
A few words more about West Point before we move on.
Okay, great.
Because it's a lesson we can all learn from what happened there in the early 50s.
It was a cheating scandal.
Oh, yeah.
I don't know if you remember that.
I discussed with you earlier that it's about as near to a perfect environment as you could find in that everyone's equal, of course, except the plebs in the class system.
But for example, no one can have money there.
So it doesn't make any difference if you're the son of a millionaire or if you're from a poor-form country like I was.
You're all there, all the same thing, uniforms and so forth.
through the years, athletes live with their own company.
The only difference, and they ate with their own company.
The only difference was if they would go any afternoon for two hours out to football training or any other athletic sport.
And if they weren't out for varsity, of course, they'd go out to intramural.
Everybody exercised.
The great teams during the
World War II, which, of course, the Military Academy had the advantage because a lot of the great athletes went there.
Foreign education, also.
I don't mean to necessarily draft Dodgers, but obviously the reason why West Point had a real powerful team during the war years, undefeated and that sort of thing.
Post-war, then they were competing with other colleges on an equal basis.
And, of course, Notre Dame was always their arch rival, even more so than
in the Naval Academy.
And that became almost a religious war.
They played in New York, you know, using Yankee Stadium.
Always a sellout, of course.
And you had this tremendous competition.
So to compete, the military academy was given, I think it was 30 appointments.
Norm is congressional, and there's several categories, but normally they're congressional appointees.
But they had authority to get 30 scholarships, approximately.
So they started recruiting athletes, and they shouldn't have ever been recruited, as it turned out later on, because they couldn't keep up.
They couldn't compete.
They couldn't make the grades.
That's right.
And so now they moved them into a
like we have at A&M and all the schools where athletes live together and have a training table.
So they lived together.
You could call it an athletic company or a football company.
And they ate together on a training table, ate differently.
And they were recruited.
So these people tended to identify themselves more with the Army athletic program than they did West Point and the cadets.
duty on and country.
And A&M had two sections academically.
I mean, at West Point.
They had two sections academically.
And so you had one group that went at one time, and every day they had a test.
Then they passed on those to the other section between the answers to it.
And, of course, the smart ones did that.
They didn't have these dumb-ups doing it, and everybody would fail.
So that was their attempt to keep these so-called cadets proficient academically so they'd be eligible to even stay there because they would be separated immediately if they didn't do their job.
Now, involved in that scheme was Red Blake, who was really a fine individual, his son.
handsome young man, smart.
He was at the head of his way.
He wasn't a star man.
He wasn't the top academically, but he was way above the average.
But he felt obligated not letting his father know anything about this, that he would help out on this.
So he was sort of the leader of organizing how we're going to get the answers to these other guys.
And they did.
And that went along until finally... For how long did this go on?
It probably went on for maybe as much as a year.
I don't know.
But one or the other.

And another thing, it was so well organized, they knew who they couldn't trust, you know, in other words, those who were still duty on in country, lie, cheat, or steal, and won't tolerate anybody who does.
And so some way they had it so well organized, these young people were isolated and wasn't aware of it.
Till one day, one of those stumbled upon this.
I guess he overheard it or something.
So he immediately, as you're obligated to in the honor system, to report it, see, what he had heard and who the individuals were.
So they immediately investigated.
And they started looking into this.
So some of these players that had been recruited went to Coach Blake and said, this is what the situation is.
They've asked us to
testify and a lot of people involved with this and it'll decimate the entire program.
And Blake was shocked.
He really was.
He says, you immediately go tell everything you know about it.
And you encourage everybody else.
We're going to get this cleared up once and for all.
What is the result?
About 40 something around that.
I've even forgotten.
We're, of course, separated from the school.
And what really broke Blake's heart and a lot of other people, including those with his son, who should have never been contaminated with that kind of thing.
But anyway, he was as guilty as the rest of them because he passed on information.
And so, of course, the moral of that story, the lesson we learned is that if you deviate from custom in something that's real fine,
for the short-term game, you know, winning football game.
Because they weren't making money.
They didn't like a great big athletic program.
Well, of course, they're supporting their own program.
But it isn't a case of trying to compete worldwide or nationwide, like Notre Dame, for example, with their recruiting program.
All they did is just disgrace military academy.
It took them, oh gosh, several years to get over that.
And it took several years for that.
The athletic program actually has never recovered from that.
Because you get some athletes now, you try to recruit them to go to West Point.
Of course, now everybody thinks about professional football and big contracts.
Sure.
Well, just like their graduate now, who's a lieutenant down at Benning.
He worked out with the Cowboys because he hoped to do like Staubach here.
He fulfilled his obligation.
to still be able to play, but he doesn't have the talent to stall back there.
Well, that's the end of the West Point idea.
Vince Lombardi was there as assistant coach, but he wasn't involved with this.
He was assistant coach before, there for one year.
Did you feel that Congress put a lot of pressure on West Point?
In what way?
Did Congress, as far as the investigations were concerned today, I mean, I've heard sometimes that, you know,

the military academies are sort of a nice whipping boy for uh congressman no i don't think so not now i don't know about this last you know we've had another team i don't know anything about that now that might apply in that case because i think downey from up in new york personally because that's in his area sure that's pointed then he has a responsibility but no there was absolutely no pressure in fact uh
The reason why you would sabotage, you would demolish the school if you permitted that to happen.
And I think this last time they tried, some of the cadets thought there were so many involved that they wouldn't possibly investigate this.
Look what a disgrace this would be if they would try to paper over it.
But it wasn't the case with that athletic thing.
I was all out on that.
mainly because you had to coach himself.
He was such a shock.
Now, he's, of course, a graduate, but he is just a tremendous guy and a leader.
That's the thing about it.
He was getting good results out of the normal cadets that you would get through appointments.
Of course, you get a lot of good athletes by normal appointments, congressional, because that's who you're looking for.
In the high school, some of these outstanding young men go to West Point.
They're high academic.
They're captain of their team.
No, I was there at that time, and there was no pressure at all.
In fact, I think they felt sorry for the situation.
Sorry that it occurred.
They weren't sympathetic with a cheater.
Well, let's turn to the next assignment, and that's advisor to the G-3 of the Imperial Iranian Army.
And this was 1951 to 1954?
No, that was two years.
I went in 1952 to 1954, wasn't it?
Yeah.
Yeah, because in 1955 you attended the Air Forces Staff College.
Okay.
Tell me about this job, all your functions and duties.
Well, I was assigned there initially, doesn't show on that, as advisor to the commanding general staff college, school there, let's say.
And I arrived in the commanding general there, General Zimmerman.
He got to know me.
I didn't know him previously.
He decided he wanted me to perform a duties of the G3 of the mission and G3 of fighting to the Iranian army.
So I took that job and the one who was going to have that, he went to the command and staff school.
And our mission, the mission of the Army, the Armed Forces of the U.S. was to
train and equip an army for internal security.
Not even defense, of course, that would be far, but it was to maintain internal security or stability in that part of the world.
Same thing we're looking for today.
And it wasn't easy for several reasons.
One reason is that most of the army was illiterate.
Most of the nation was illiterate as far as that's concerned.
Obviously, the Army would be.
But the Army did have a program, very helpful, in that they did teach them at least to read and write.
And it was difficult also because while the officers gave lip service,
to wanting to improve training, to enhance the standards of the armed forces.
They wanted to do it their way.
And their way was, you never get out in the field and train.
You always come back in the barrack.
They said they didn't have any money for benzene or gasoline, but in fact,
They did have, but couldn't get it, although Iran wasn't booming like it was when the shell was there with all this income for the price of oil.
So we only provided that equipment, like trucks, some small tanks or artillery pieces, and trained them to use it.
But to give you an example, our difficulty with Iranian, and it's typical of Iranian, is that we had a meeting because we had arranged, got the benzene for them.
We were going to take them to the field of division and give them some field training, which they hadn't been out in the field for a long time.
So we had this big meeting with all of the Iranian, the G3 of the Iranian Army.
The chief of staff of the Iranian Army also was there.
So we all just
planned this exercise and gave a date.
And all of the means were provided.
And so when the date approached, I went out to join in the exercise.
Wasn't anybody there.
And I went back to the department of Army
building, the office, and there's all of them in the office.
I went to the G3.
I said, well, we're supposed to be out.
What happened?
He said, well, we decided we wouldn't go.
I said, well, why didn't you tell me?
He said, well, and he attended our command of Staff Guard.
He said, sit down, Colonel Andrews.
I want to talk to you.
He said, you must understand, in our countries, sometimes we have commissions in order to do nothing.
Well, I said, why didn't you tell me that's what we were doing, having a commission in order to do nothing?
He said, because we like you so much.
We don't want to disappoint you.
I know how you feel about this.
The general, who was Zimmerman at that time, later on McClure.
Well, that opened my eyes then, because then I knew that you're going to have to approach him entirely differently.
How did you change your approach?
Well, it was very difficult, but
You had to work, and we didn't have any advisors in the field.
You had to work then through the G3, talk to him.
But I went down to the division commander.
And in this instance, it was General Bakhtiari, who was a brother-in-law of the Shah.
And he was very receptive.
Oh, yes, he wanted to do that.
He actually warped the digs and got out.
We worked with him, and he got all set.
Then I talked to him and said, now, General Bakhtar is all ready to go on this.
And unless you disagree, this is the way we're supposed to conduct it.
And they'd say, Bali, oh, yes, that's fine.
Another example of Iranians, they had a small parachute group.
We had about one officer and I think eight people.
They had C-47s that they were flying a few.
And they had Azerbaijani Day.
That's the day they celebrate.
They say, the Iranians say, they kicked the Russians out of Azerbaijan.
But you remember Harry Truman told them that they better get out of there or else.
So each year.
So they have the Russians there.
We're all in there on the attache sitting there.
So the planes fly over and out jumps the parachute.
But they continue on.
And another stick comes out.
And here comes another plane and another stick.
And the Russians sitting next to me, I got a guy to interpret.
They were talking.
I said, what did they say?
I said, the Russians just said they had no idea that the Iranians had that many paratroopers.
Well, what they had done, see, the live jumped out first.
And they threw out dummies all along at a greater distance.
And they had troops on the ground hidden, you know.
So when they got down, they all came up all intact towards the target.
And I could go on and on.
We gave them trucks, and then we gave them, of course, antifreeze to put in the truck.
They thought they could fool the truck by not putting it in there, so they didn't put the antifreeze in.
And they sold it.
Of course, all of the blocks burst.
It gets real cold in a lot of areas in Iran in the wintertime.
Another example of some of their thinking is we had a
terrible C-47 Iranian Airlines crashed up near Tehran during Christmas time in a snowstorm.
And when it turned out, looking at the records, they had 10 more people in that C-47 than was safe.
But they weren't on the manifest.
Loading them in Abaddon, this guy thought that if he didn't,
missed them on the manifest, see the plane wouldn't know the difference.
This is just a man-made rule, you know.
And that's what you're faced with, with training these people.
They have their own approach to a problem, their own set of values, and it's very difficult to penetrate.
But as I talked about yesterday, Iran, of course, as you know, being not a homogeneous nation,
